children.subject:
Honestly, I would just say, GPA and the Berkeley name doesn’t matter in your equation of getting a good job.

Here’s what you do: learn material you enjoy in classes. If you don’t want to go to grad school, you don’t have to study little details you’re not not interested in, but your GPA might become lower, which doesn’t matter as long as you graduate.

while you take classes, code 1 hour a day outside of class. Or do interview prep 1 problem a day at least. Fix your resume and possibly LinkedIn.

you have no control over how people will judge your gpa and school name. So I wouldn’t worry about them. Don’t list your gpa unless you feel proud of it on resume, and improve your skills everyday.

The truth is any of us can get a job anywhere we want as a software engineer if we have a resume that shows skills(projects count), and interview skills. This stressful idea in which gpa and brand name help is not healthy imo. Yes, recruiters are looking for the “best”, and gpa and school rankings help them. But there’s plenty of open slots.

i have friends below 3.0 and got offers from all the prestigious companies. They had projects an interview prep.

in conclusion, don’t worry about how recruiters will judge you for school name and gpa. Just work hard everyday and results will come. Even if some companies have GPA cutoffs, find a way to get past it or just be wait few years after undergrad and they won’t care anymore.

In school, just work hard everyday and it will all work out. After school, work hard and it will all work out.

Quick add on to what I said, companies should list their "min GPA" when you apply for internships. There shouldn't be any min GPA once you're not a new grad or student anymore. Again, i'm sure with a phenomenal resume and networking, you can bypass this requirement. In the end, it's really just there to make the recruiters' lives easier when picking candidates to interview.

As a freshmen, I heard lots of opinions as to what GPA is "solid" for getting a good internship/job. Are there any opinions from more senior students? Also, I believe curriculum at UC Berkeley is much more difficult than some other schools, will the brand of "Berkeley" give an advantage during recruiting? Thanks!

history.subject: Should I ask career questions on this piazza as well?
